answers: CAR T-Cell Therapy [or Chimeric Antigen Receptor T-Cell Therapy]
parts: Name this cancer therapy in which T-Cells are modified to target tumor specific antigens such as CD19 by expressing different T-cell receptors. The FDA recently approved its use for acute lymphoblastic leukemia.
Ordinarily, T cell receptors are produced in the body through this error prone process in which genetic fragments are randomly rearranged and joined together through non-homologous end joining.

V(D)J recombination is also used to produce the variable domain of this class of glycoproteins that possess a heavy chain region and a light chain region. These proteins bind to antigens during an immune response.

answers: Tammany Hall [or Society of St. Tammany; or Sons of St. Tammany; or the Columbian Order; or the Tammany Society]
Thomas E. Dewey [or Thomas Edmund Dewey]
parts: Name this “Boy Mayor of New York” who lost the 1918 mayoral election to John Francis Hylan. His grandfather of the same name was a Young Ireland activist who urged Irish-Americans to support the Confederacy.
John Purroy Mitchel gained his reputation as a reformer by taking on this political machine. In the 19th century, this super-corrupt New York organization was controlled by William “Boss” Tweed.

This New York politician took on Tammany Hall while serving as Fiorello La Guardia’s special prosecutor in the 1930s. Also known for his investigation of Dutch Schultz, he later ran for office with running mate Earl Warren..
Name this paper by W.V.O. Quine which calls for a turn away from the traditional “armchair” discussions of its title discipline.
Quine argued that epistemology should focus on how people attain knowledge, not what knowledge is. This author of Phaedo and Meno defined knowledge as “justified true belief” in his Theaetetus.

Quine wanted to stay away from “folk psychology,” which contains concepts that do not actually exist according to this view. Daniel Dennett expresses a strong form of this view that denies qualia concepts like pain.

Name this Han Kang novel, in which Yeong-hye Cheong’s family has an “intervention” after she starts the title practice. She has sex with a man with flowers painted on his body and becomes gradually more plant-like.
Han Kang is from this country, home to the author of “Azalea,” Kim Sowol. This country’s poet Ko Un wrote about his visit to its totalitarian neighbor in his collection North and South.
In this Kenzaburo Oe novel, the Korean “Emperor” is a grocery store owner against whom Takashi organizes a group of football-playing children. Taskashi then rather memorably kills himself.

answers: isochoric process [prompt on anything mentioning constant volume]
parts: Name this kind of process, in which pressure times volume raised to the nth power is held constant. The n in the previous statement is the namesake index of this process.
When this law applies to a polytropic process, the ratio of energy transfer as heat and energy transfer as work for each step is constant. This law is simply stated as PV equals n R T.
A polytropic process with index infinity is this kind of process, which also appears as a vertical line in a PV diagram.

answers: Chancellor of the Exchequer [or Chancellor and the Under-Treasurer of Her Majesty’s Exchequer; prompt on partial answers]
parts: Name this Conservative politician and opponent of William Gladstone who is the only Jew to have become Prime Minister.
Disraeli held this position during the two ministries of Lord Derby. The holder of this office gives the Mansion House speech every June, and their official residence is 11 Downing Street.
After becoming Prime Minister, Disraeli remarked that he had climbed to the top of this two word object, which may refer to the difficulty of a Jew reaching high office.
Name this word that accompanies the words “in Blue” and “in Rivets” in the titles of popular works by George Gershwin. Rachmaninov wrote a set of these works on a “theme by Paganini.”
This virtuoso violinist was inspired by lautareasca music to compose his Romanian Rhapsodies. He also collaborated with Merri Franquin to create a popular work for trumpet and piano called Legende.
This German composer composed Alto Rhapsody based on a Goethe poem about a lost soul in a wasteland.
Name this empire, which produced works of art such as the Hagia Sophia and many gold-leaf-backed icons depicting flat, stylized religious figures.
This Byzantine Romanos-group ivory triptych presents a Deesis scene of Christ on a throne with a book, while the back shows a Garden of Eden with two cypresses leaning towards a cross.
This Sienese artist was influenced by Byzantine styles to create his Maesta and his Rucellai Madonna, both of which show a Virgin and child surrounded by angels and saints.

Name this “True-blue Protestant poet,” who is satirized in a mock-heroic work beginning “All human things are subject to decay” in which he solemnly swears to remain dull and is crowned by the king Nonsense.
In addition to mocking Shadwell in “MacFlecknoe,” this poet wrote about Palmyra and Leonidas in Marriage a la Mode and described his conversion to Catholicism in “The Hind and the Panther.”
Dryden satirized the rebellion of the Earl of Shaftsbury and the Duke of Monmouth, represented as the two title Biblical characters rebelling against David in this monarchic poem.

answers: National Museum of African American History and Culture (be kind and accept any reasonable answer suggesting a museum or Smithsonian institute of African American History)
parts: Name this British-Ghanaian architect who created the light installation Your black horizon at the Venice Biennale and more recently designed the Nobel Peace Centre in Oslo.

Adjaye was the lead designer of this project, the latest Smithsonian museum. It is located on the National Mall and takes the rough form of an inverted ziggurat that supposedly visually references a Yoruban crown.
That museum was constructed on a plot of land set aside for a museum in this man’s 1791 plan for Washington, D.C.
Name this state described by Mihaly Csíkszentmihályi (me-hi chick-sent-me-hi), in which a person is fully immersed in and enjoying a challenging activity.

This greedy algorithm computes the maximum flow in a network by sending the maximum possible flow along an augmenting path with nonzero capacity from source to sink, then finding maximum flow on the residual graph.
This type of chaotic flow, often contrasted with laminar flow, occurs at high Reynolds numbers when inertial forces overcome viscous forces.
Name this physicist who published the paper “Transgressing the Boundaries: Towards a Transformative Hermeneutics of Quantum Gravity” before revealing that it was complete nonsense.
A.D. Harvey falsified a newly-discovered interview between this author of A Tale of Two Cities and Dostoyevsky, before it was uncovered as part of a fake network of arguing scholars.
In another academic hoax, the 18th-century professor James MacPherson claimed to have discovered poems like Fingal written by this Celtic hero, a son of Finn MacCool, but he just wrote them himself.
Name this physicist. He also names a type of plasma pinch in which a current flowing in the plasma produces an azimuthal magnetic field which compresses it.

Z-pinches can generate poloidal magnetic fields, but these devices generate toroidal magnetic fields as well to confine plasmas in the shape of a torus. Due to their large currents, they often suffer from instabilities.
Tokamaks are considered the leading candidates for reactors which would produce energy by this process. This process combines two nuclei to form a heavier one, releasing energy in the process.

answers: Maggie the Cat [accept Margaret Pollitt; prompt on “Pollitt”]
parts: Name this character, who locks liquor away from her alcoholic husband Brick until they conceive so they can get an inheritance from the dying Big Daddy Pollitt.
Maggie is the title Cat on a Hot Tin Roof in a play by this writer of The Glass Menagerie.

In Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, Brick and Big Daddy rail against this term. Brick claims that “liquor is one way out and death’s the other” from this term, which he blames for people labeling his relationship with Skipper as gay.

answers: Otto von Bismarck [or Otto Eduard Leopold, Prince of Bismarck, Duke of Lauenburg]
parts: This big game hunter founded a hunting association called the Shikar Club. This person fought under Cecil Rhodes during the Matabele war and names an elite unit that used terror tactics during the Second Chimurenga.
This German Chancellor sought to create European spheres of influence by hosting the Berlin Conference. This person gave the Blood and Iron speech to advocate for German unification.

The Berlin Conference helped allow Germany to consolidate control over a colony in Southwest Africa where they subjected this ethnic group, the Nama, and the San people to a genocide under general Lothar von Trotha.

Based on the Egyptian Book of the Dead, you believe your soul will be led into the presence of this god of the afterlife. Set tricked him into climbing into a coffin and chopped him up, but his wife Iris put him back together.

The Book of the Dead says that your soul will be weighed against the goddess Ma'at, represented by one of these things. If the scales don’t balance because your soul is too impure, Ammit the Devourer eats your heart.
You believe that this part of the soul will survive your death and go to the afterworld, unlike the ka, which is separated from your body at death, and the ba, which moves between life and death.
Name this Roman prefect responsible for the trial and crucifixion of Jesus. His wife had a dream that told her that Jesus was innocent, but her husband failed to heed her warning.
In Genesis, Abimelech takes this beautiful woman into his harem but receives a dream from God warning him not to touch her, since she’s already married.

After God comes to him in a dream, Jacob awakes and says “This can be but the house of God, and this is the gate of the heavens.” He then sets up a pillar, anoints it with oil, and gives it this name.

answers: hunger strikes [prompt on “fasting” or descriptive answers like “refusing to eat”]
parts: Name this action which also caused the death of Potti Sreeramulu, who sought the creation of Andhra State for the Telugu people.
This other Indian leader used hunger strikes to great effect as part of his doctrine of satyagraha and successfully achieved Indian independence from Britain.

Jatin Das and a man with this last name went on hunger strike while jailed for allegedly killing police officers. Two bodyguards with this last name assassinated Indira Gandhi after she ordered an attack on the Golden Temple.

answers: NP-complete [prompt on NP or NP-hard; accept P or NP only if they provide a correct proof that P=NP]
parts: Name this property of certain computational problems which means that they can be solved in polynomial time by a non-deterministic Turing machine.

One of Karp’s original NP-complete problems was this problem of determining whether, for a given graph, there is a collection of vertices such that every edge connects to at least one vertex in the collection.
The class NP is often contrasted with this other complexity class. This complexity class contains problems that can be solved in polynomial time by a Turing machine.
Name this work, whose narrator is “midway in the journey of our life” when he evades a leopard, a lion, and a she-wolf in a forest.
The Inferno was written as part of the Divine Comedy by this Italian poet, who depicted himself going to Paradise to see his love Beatrice.
These people are barked at by Cerberus in the third circle of hell. Dante meets one of these people, Ciacco, who is forced to lie flattened by the rain.
